Thanks @nihui, @tqchen, @jwfromm. 

I generalized this approach to handle devices that don't support the push descriptor (see the Stream::LaunchDeferred APIs), and devices that don't support dedicated allocation APIs, and removed the previous runtime implementation as @tqchen suggested. I also added some more tests which (under Vulkan API validation) revealed some thread safety bugs.

I think this should be closer to something that is acceptable, so I'll remove the RFC and WIP tags, this should be ready for review. 

File/class structure is certainly up for debate. I'm fine with whatever folks propose.
Yeah, as @cchung100m suggested, please open a thread in the discussion forum.

@weberlo @joshpoll What should I do to make the parser pass in all global defs to be typechecked simultaneously to allow for mutual recursion in the text format?
I have no idea what is causing the error in `test_nested_matches`, would appreciate any suggestions (I am looking into it)
Ah the error had something to do with not being able to unify a type var. I think this may have something to do with how the typechecker instantiates type vars.
@slyubomirsky I can help tomorrow, can you come in and pair program?

Will do. Whatever it is, I think it might be something within the unifier because this doesn't happen when the functions are type checked one at a time, only when all the constraints are populated and resolved at the end.

Found a cludge that will fix it but we should figure out the real problem (I think something is not being instantiated or being instantiated poorly).

edit: The nature of the error in `test_nested_matches` is that the return type of `flatten` is `l(b)` where `b` is a concrete type var and the unifier is failing to match that with `l(nat())`. Somewhere a concrete type var isn't getting eliminated.

further edit: This may also be a case of something we don't actually want to support right now. I.e., we might just want to maintain that if you have an explicit type var in your signature, you should have it everywhere in that function. Still, it's very strange that it worked before but not with these changes (which I would not have guessed would affect it)

Don't know what the deal is with the resnet batching test failure (unless it's just flaky)

edit: Whatever the deal is, it's certainly reproducible so it might well be caused by these changes...
Should we use c++14 by default when available?
personally I dont see why not. python2 is deprecated and C++14 is out 5 years ago. giving how fast deep learning is moving I see no incentive to restrict ourselves to 11.
I think C++14 is the default since clang-6.0. But will our submodules cause problem?

Thank you for the very detailed background explanation @anijain2305 .
One thing that I am not fully understand is, with this patch, `uint8` data and `int8` kernel which feeds to `nn.conv2d` are asymmetric, how they should be computed by VNNI extension regarding the accumulated multiplication part?
Hi guys, I am a bit busy this week, will come back to this (for the RFC part) later :)
Thanks @yzhliu
@jwfromm @yzhliu @masahi @kazum can you guys help to review this PR?
@kevinthesun @yzhliu ready for review
@jroesch @MarisaKirisame any other feedback? The CI error was a timeout waiting to find an executor, I'll retrigger a dummy change.

> Thank you for the very detailed background explanation @anijain2305 .
> One thing that I am not fully understand is, with this patch, `uint8` data and `int8` kernel which feeds to `nn.conv2d` are asymmetric, how they should be computed by VNNI extension regarding the accumulated multiplication part?

By the time, the data and kernel comes to conv, they are just uint8 and int8 numbers. The HW has no notion of asymmetric and symmetric. It will just take two tensors, one uint8 and other int8 and do dot product. So, I don't think asymmetry plays a role at the level of `nn.conv2d`.

Side note - If suppose both the inputs were symmetric. The `qnn.conv2d` will Canonicalize to just `nn.conv2d`. In that case also, `nn,.conv2d` will only have two tensors, one uint8 and other int8. Whether they were symmetric or not, `nn.conv2d` (and also VNNI) is completely unaware of that.

Please let me know if I am missing anything.
One concern is that, MXNet is using c++11, and for the recently merged feature (use tvm to write mxnet op), we need to compile TVM in MXNet, it will cause problem.
Thanks @MarisaKirisame @weberlo

Smaller repro for the type unification issue I face above (I will add this as a test once we've figured out what's going wrong):
```
def test_list_id():
    a = relay.TypeVar('a')
    x = relay.Var('x', l(a)) # fails without this annotation
    h = relay.Var('h')
    t = relay.Var('t')
    list_id = relay.GlobalVar('list_id')
    list_id_func = relay.Function(
        [x],
        relay.Match(
            x,
            [
                relay.Clause(
                    relay.PatternConstructor(cons, [relay.PatternVar(h), relay.PatternVar(t)]),
                    cons(h, list_id(t))),
                relay.Clause(relay.PatternConstructor(nil), nil())
            ]),
        l(a), [a])

    main = relay.GlobalVar('main')
    main_func = relay.Function([], list_id(cons(make_nat_expr(p, 1), nil())))
    # type checking will fail here if there's no annotation on the arg
    mod.add_multiple({main : main_func, list_id : list_id_func})
```

Recursion is critical, as an example like this one will succeed without annotations: 

```
def test_hd_hd():
    hd_hd = relay.GlobalVar('hd_hd')
    a = relay.TypeVar('a')
    x = relay.Var('x') # works without an extra annotation
    h = relay.Var('h')
    hd_hd_func = relay.Function(
        [x],
        relay.Match(
            x, [
                relay.Clause(relay.PatternConstructor(cons, [relay.PatternVar(h), relay.PatternWildcard()]), some(hd(h))),
                relay.Clause(relay.PatternWildcard(), none())
            ]),
        optional(l(a)), [a])

    main = relay.GlobalVar('main')
    test_list = cons(cons(make_nat_expr(p, 1), nil()), nil())
    main_func = relay.Function([], hd_hd(test_list))

    mod.add_multiple({main: main_func, hd_hd: hd_hd_func})
```
(Note that even in this latter case, the type for `hd_hd` will still have an incomplete type in it, which should actually be an error!)

Hi @wujiaqi6630, if you want to see the C source code that is generated, you can use `func.get_source()` because `func` is the C source module where as `m` is the DSO module. Only the C source module supports GetSource.

```
import tvm
n = tvm.var("n")
m = tvm.var("m")
A0 = tvm.placeholder((m, n), name='A0')
k = tvm.reduce_axis((0, n), 'k')
B0, B1 = tvm.compute((m, ), lambda i: (tvm.sum(A0[i, k], axis=k), tvm.sum(A0[i, k] * A0[i, k], axis=k)), name='B')
s = tvm.create_schedule(B0.op)
print(tvm.lower(s, [A0, B0, B1], simple_mode=True))
```

But that does not quite work out of box. I tried some hacks but I think this requires new compute pattern as you suggested.

You'd need to change everywhere where `self.module` is updated (i.e., [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/relay/_parser.py#L501), [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/relay/_parser.py#L523), and [here](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/relay/_parser.py#L543)) to instead collect the defs in a dict that can be converted into a module all at once [when the visitor finishes](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/relay/_parser.py#L756).

Mostly looks good and it is good to have a more explicit solution to the problem of incomplete matches. A couple of issues besides the questions I've labeled:
* Test cases for hashing and alpha-equal would be good too (they're dull but if anything goes wrong with those, it could be a problem in many areas)
* We'd have to update various interpreters to handle fatal nodes and have test cases for those

Hi @anijain2305 , I have been busy with some other stuff, sorry for the delayed reply.

I think the `int8` (weight) should be requantized to symmetric representation rather than adding the zero point, because the value density of `uint8` and `int8` representation is different. Therefore, the `uint8` and `int8` VNNI arithmetic makes sense. And, the bias may need to shift (I mean value shift, not the bit shift) to cooperate with this VNNI design. I may propose some equations if this doesn't seem very straightforward.

> The HW has no notion of asymmetric and symmetric.

Absolutely yes, that's what the system developer should be carefull :)

And, sorry if I have any misunderstanding :)

@jackwish I think I understand what you are referring to, but I am talking about a different abstraction. Allow me to explain. Let's leave asymmetric, symmetric and VNNI off the discussion for now.

Suppose, we have a tensor of floating point numbers. We can represent them in one quantized representation `Q_a` with `scale_a` and `zp_a`. So, 

`FP_value = scale_a * (Q_a - zp_a)`

Now, I can have another quantized representation that can map to the exact same floating point numbers as that `Q_a` tensor.

For example

`FP_value = scale_a * ( Q_a - zp_a + 128 - 128)`
`FP_value = scale_a * ( (Q_a - 128) - (zp_a - 128))`

So, here, we can have another quantized representation `Q_b` with (`scale_a`, `zp_b'), where 

`Q_b = Q_z - 128`
`zp_b = zp_a - 128`

Any operator that was consuming this tensor as input remains unchanged. It will still get same represented floating point values (only the quantized values and zero point has changed, while the floating point values are still same). 

In the context of PR, Q_a is `u8` and I want to bring all the values in `i8` range. This can be done by using the above equation. 

Essentially, following thing happens

~~~
# Original

        u8       u8
        |        |
        qnn.conv2d

# After QnnLegalize


       u8       u8
        |        |
        |        requantize to i8 using above equations
        |        |
        qnn.conv2d
~~~

If we agree on this, the following comment should also help - https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/42195a48e01c4850a7a89d2ae586740821d76555/python/tvm/relay/qnn/transform.py#L71-L107
@vinx13 can this be merged?

Yes, you are right @anijain2305, I was focus on factorizing `uint8 * int8` too much, leading to misunderstanding of the legalization.

Sorry for the that, and thank you for the kind patient and detailed explain :)
